title: Goldman Sachs Profit Rises on Deal Bonanza; Wall Street firm's investment bankers had their second-best quarter on record
text:
JPMorgan Chase & Co., Bank of America Corp., Citigroup Inc. and Wells Fargo & Co. released some of the money they had set aside to deal with pandemic losses, a sign of their confidence in the bumpy economic recovery.

Goldman CEO David Solomon said on a call with analysts that he believes the pandemic's worst effects on the global economy are likely over but that some risks remain. Congress, for example, is heading toward another debt-ceiling standoff and deadlocked over infrastructure proposals.

Goldman executives are paying close attention to Washington developments and inflation, the Delta variant and the "complicated" U.S.-China relationship, Mr. Solomon said.

"Taken together, these items have the potential to be a headwind to growth," Mr. Solomon said.

That hasn't stopped the deal making party. Goldman's investment bankers brought in $3.7 billion in fees, the second-best quarter on record and 88% higher than a year ago. They earned $1.65 billion just from advising on mergers and acquisitions, a quarterly record and more than triple the year-ago results. Advisory fees also more than tripled at Morgan Stanley and Citigroup, and more than doubled at JPMorgan.

Companies that went into survival mode when the pandemic first hit are now eager to partner up. Global deal volume hit $1.43 trillion in the quarter, up from about $1 trillion in the third quarter of 2020, according to Dealogic. Bond offerings and equity offerings have slowed but remain higher than normal.

More deals are on the way: Bank executives said their pipelines for potential future deals remain full, an indicator corporate chieftains are feeling confident. Still, Mr. Solomon said that the lightning-fast deal pace wasn't sustainable. "There will be some speed bumps along the way," he said.

Third-quarter trading revenue was more of a mixed bag. It fell 5% at JPMorgan and Citigroup. It jumped 23% at Goldman, to $5.61 billion.

Bond trading came back to earth after a supercharged 2020, when nervous companies raced to raise debt. Now, investors are trying to determine the new normal of trading activity. Bond-trading revenue was flat at Goldman and down at the other big banks.

Executives across the banking industry struck a confident tone on the economy, saying that the impacts of the pandemic and world-wide supply-chain are ebbing. But those same issues have roiled the stock market, and the banks have taken advantage of the volatility. Almost all of them recorded double-digit increases in stock-trading revenue. Goldman's stock-trading revenue surged 51%.

For all its Wall Street prowess, Goldman is trying to expand on Main Street. Revenue in the consumer and wealth-management division rose 35% to $2.02 billion, or about 15% of the firm's third-quarter revenue. The unit includes Goldman's Marcus consumer bank and the team serving wealthy clients.

The bank recently announced plans to buy specialty lender GreenSky Inc., which arranges loans for big one-time purchases like renovation projects. Loans in Goldman's credit card unit doubled.

Overall, Goldman reported profit of $5.38 billion, or $14.93 a share. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected $10.14 a share. Revenue was $13.61 billion. Analysts had expected $11.72 billion.

Compensation expense rose 2% to $3.17 billion. Total operating expenses were $6.59 billion, up 6% from the same period last year.

The bank's return on equity, a measure of how profitably it uses shareholders' money, was 22.5% on an annualized basis.

Goldman shares rose 3.8% Friday, or $14.87, to $406.07. They are up 54% for the year.

Write to Orla McCaffrey at orla.mccaffrey@wsj.com

Goldman Sachs Profit Rises on Deal Bonanza
